text:
I haven't had any need to review the Windows Update logs in a very long time
since our server patching process is very streamlined using MECM. But as a few
mentioned, when a patch breaks a server it's helpful to have the logs point in
the right direction of what the cause of the failure is. In some cases, I didn't
even have to look at the logs because the stop error gave me all the information
I needed to research online and find the root cause. It would more a lot more
helpful if we can get more information in MECM/WSUS instead of searching through
cryptic logs.

metadata.topic: Re: Do you look at update logs?
metadata.subject: Re: [patchmanagement] Re: Do you look at update logs?

metadata.email_text_original:
Re: Do you look at update logs? 
I haven't had any need to review the Windows Update logs in a very long time
since our server patching process is very streamlined using MECM. But as a few
mentioned, when a patch breaks a server it's helpful to have the logs point in
the right direction of what the cause of the failure is. In some cases, I didn't
even have to look at the logs because the stop error gave me all the information
I needed to research online and find the root cause. It would more a lot more
helpful if we can get more information in MECM/WSUS instead of searching through
cryptic logs. 
On Thu, Nov 9, 2023 at 7:43 AM James Iversen <jeiversen@gmail.com
Link: https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/patchmanagement/CAGaCHK4KV2ns3AQY61QvYu%3Da8X2gOa9ozLUUEQLzHLX-tF1Tig%40mail.gmail.com
